cs.CC, cs.DS, cs.DM, cs.CG, cs.LO. 

The paper deals with the problem of finding the length of the longest path in planar directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), which is a fundamental problem in computer science. The paper presents two different algorithms that solve this problem in unambiguous logspace UL, which is a complexity class that captures problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine that uses logarithmic space and always produces a unique output. This suggests that the paper belongs to the computational complexity (cs.CC) and data structures and algorithms (cs.DS) sub-categories. 

Moreover, the paper also discusses the extension of the result to toroidal DAGs, which are DAGs that can be embedded on a torus without any edge crossings. This suggests that the paper may also belong to the computational geometry (cs.CG) sub-category. 

Finally, the problem of finding the longest path in DAGs is closely related to the problem of finding the diameter of graphs, which is a well-studied problem in discrete mathematics (cs.DM) and graph theory (cs.DS). Additionally, the paper uses techniques from logic and complexity theory, which are also relevant to the sub-category of logic in computer science (cs.LO).
